articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) held an enthusiastic January indoor star party, featuring guest Walter Scott Houston, which also served as a board meeting. Key discussions included plans for Astronomy Day 1980, which is a nation-wide event with a prize from Edmund Scientific, and the nomination of Paul Zurakewski for the G. Bruce Blair gold medal. The club is also seeking a new publicity chairman.

articles.title: WANTS ADS
articles.summary: This article is a classifieds section featuring multiple advertisements for astronomical equipment. It includes listings for various telescopes, such as a C-8, 6-inch, 10-inch, and 12-3/8-inch reflectors, along with accessories like mounts, eyepieces, and filters. The ads cover both items for sale and specific equipment being sought, with options for direct purchase or trade.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: Three new comets have recently been identified, comprising two faint recoveries and one bright discovery, bringing the year's total to twelve. The article details Periodic Comet Reinmuth I (1979j) and Periodic Comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 2 (1979k), both faint recoveries by Harvard astronomers. Most notably, Comet Bradfield (1979l) was discovered by William Bradfield as a bright magnitude 5 object, expected to become visible in the northern hemisphere in late January.

articles.title: The Comets of 1979
articles.summary: This article provides a comprehensive listing of comet observations and discoveries made during the year 1979. It details both new discoveries by amateur and professional astronomers, including names, countries, discovery dates, and magnitudes. Additionally, it lists professional recoveries of previously known returning comets, noting the recoverers, countries, dates, and magnitudes.

articles.title: COMETS IN THEIR EYES:
articles.summary: This article introduces two prominent historical figures, Edmund Halley and Charles Messier, in relation to comets. Halley is highlighted for his prediction of the return of the comet now named after him, despite not discovering any comets himself. Messier, though a discoverer of multiple comets, is noted as being more famous for other contributions to astronomy.

articles.title: Comet Hunters
articles.summary: This article, the initial installment of the "Comet in their eyes" series, profiles two notable comet hunters. It highlights William Bradfield, a highly successful active amateur from South Australia, detailing his equipment, observation methods, and significant number of discoveries. The text also briefly touches upon another historical figure's observing tools and catalog, setting the stage for future installments.

articles.title: Ephemeris for Comet Bradfield ( 1979l):
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Bradfield (1979l), detailing its celestial path as it transitions from the morning to evening sky and makes a close approach to Earth on January 26th. It includes a table listing the comet's Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated magnitude for dates between January 26 and February 03.

articles.title: The 1980 MESSIER MARATHON
articles.summary: The article announces the 1980 Messier Marathon, an annual star party encouraging observers to view all Messier Objects on moonless nights, scheduled for March 14-16 at Loma Prieta. Additionally, it features an observing report from Jim van Nuland detailing his November 1979 observations of Jupiter, Mars, and the rare "ringless" appearance of Saturn, highlighting a culmination of his long-term observations.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of dates and times in Pacific Standard Time (PST) when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will be on the central meridian. The list spans from January 23rd to February 29th, detailing multiple observation opportunities across the specified period. It serves as a guide for observers interested in viewing this prominent feature of Jupiter.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: This article, "Rattley Rattles," presents the results of a club questionnaire, reflecting member attitudes and preferences despite a low 15% response rate. It details feedback on general meetings, star party formats and locations, and suggestions for the club bulletin. The club board acknowledges the member input and indicates they are working to address the issues and suggestions raised.

articles.title: Directions to the alternate star party on February 16 (for those who are bored with Henry Coe State Park).
articles.summary: This satirical article provides humorously elaborate, globe-trotting directions from San Jose to an "alternate" star party in Voi, Kenya, scheduled for February 16. The directions are intentionally impractical, playfully mocking the idea of being "bored with Henry Coe State Park," while also noting a new moon perfect for observations and a possibility of solar observing.

articles.title: DECEMBER STAR PARTY AT LOMA PRIETA
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association hosted a star party on Loma Prieta mountain on December 15, 1979, attended by twenty to thirty people. Amidst clear skies and mild weather, attendees observed celestial objects with various telescopes, ranging from a 16-inch Newtonian to a Celestron 8 and 90. Notable observations included attempts at deep-sky photography of the Orion Nebula and the successful detection of the elusive Horsehead Nebula, challenging assumptions about visibility near city lights.

articles.title: Loma Prieta cont.
articles.summary: This article reports on a successful winter star party held on Loma Prieta, noting strong attendance including several newcomers, and concludes with a gathering at a local diner. It also provides the answers to an astronomy-themed crossword puzzle, 'Skyword #5.' Additionally, the piece includes several announcements, such as a Black Hole Hotline, a space symposium and film screening at Stanford University, and a discussion regarding the apparent lack of grazing occultations in Northern California for 1980.
